document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

CFB3EE68435A46E7AA25FD25170DFCF8.description: Engage in light play from various sources.

D242D6C5BA42451C95165F2A848DD779.description:
Use a variety of objects to make sound (plucking,
drumming, blowing).

0EE315B1FEA6451A8FCCAF3FB26F02DA.description:
Recognize changes in light as a result of interactions with
various objects that have differing results.

049C37C62BC54E22A5EE7A1A7F9252FB.description:
Given a group of objects (or pictures) choose the ones
that light can pass through (e.g., shine a flashlight or
laser pointer onto a mirror, trace the path of the light that
is reflected. Shine a flashlight onto black cloth and onto
white cloth, describe the differences you see).

F1AD7384686A4F14A368F43B3A55EC91.description: Sort objects by whether they reflect, refract or absorb light.

8BBDD09BE7534C88BEA6C9257E173B3C.description:
Use a variety of objects to make sound (plucking,
drumming, blowing).

F6615C010F86456D8515C4B655B9FEFC.description:
Recognize that objects (strings, drums) vibrate when they
make sound.

47598B5FF90E44DD9C254A14EF252EBA.description:
Pluck a tight string and listen to it, shorten the string and
pluck it again, describe the differences.

A25D30D5C50F4DA295291EA2F57A0731.description:
Listen to sounds at various pitches, describe them as high
or low.

C8FB3416B24F4B80A815008A37A83334.description:
Match
objects/tools/
instruments to
examples of
sounds of various
pitch.

7711127503A842D2B10E0EDFE468CB0D.description:
Demonstrate
the observable
characteristics of
how light travels.

34FFF991987749A7AFCF54B621EC9CF3.description:
Identify
properties that affect
pitch (e.g., a large
bell makes a deeper
sound than a smaller
bell).

40911722344945A88B040F8633EDC835.description:
Identify
objects that will
change the path of
light.

7F86A80BB87443A483ABAE16A7DDEFED.description:
Given
an object, explain
how you could
make a change
that would change
its pitch.

74FFE1BE5C1147018C10665CAAEAF382.description:
Given
an object, explain
how it would
change the path of
light (e.g., a mirror
will reflect light,
a dark cloth will
absorb light, etc.).

09DF87D5ECCD4831BC7581016BF46366.description:
Light and sound are
forms of energy that behave
in predictable ways. Light
travels and maintains its
direction until it interacts with
an object or moves from one
medium to another and then
it can be reflected, refracted,
or absorbed. Sound is
produced by vibrating objects
and requires a medium
through which to travel. The
rate of vibration is related
to the pitch of the sound.
Note: At this grade level,
the discussion of light and
sound should be based on
observable behavior. Waves
are introduced at the middle
school level.

002ECC7B5B0646EB9409B42ED484E753.description: Engage with objects of varying masses.

2B93847336704FACAC0584A042AE9073.description:
Using manipulatives, identify which objects require more
force (push or pull) to move.

06D0A91671FB48A59F21D4510712313F.description:
Manipulate a given model to demonstrate the force
required to move various masses.

9DD20FDE2303441F9643DDBA8B819786.description:
Predict ways to change the movement of a given model
(e.g., add bricks to a cart, push with more/less force, etc.).

B230A84A1ABA4B4FB2BB7494D006F477.description:
Demonstrate how
the speed of an
object can be
changed by adding
mass or exerting a
force.

D0B07C51E8214EC281BF31341D9924CB.description:
Identify a
change that can be
made to an object
to change its speed
(e.g., add more mass,
use more force).

0F168E94835543A3A9C2791ACE5FD778.description:
Given a
change in mass or
force, explain the
effect that change
will have on the
speed of an object.

1824E882D2CE4812BE6C01E093343AF7.description:
The amount of change
in movement of an object
is based on the mass* of
the object and the amount
of force exerted. Movement
can be measured by speed.
The speed of an object is
calculated by determining
the distance (d) traveled in a
period of time (t). Any change
in speed of an object requires
a force and is affected by the
mass of the object and the
amount of force applied. Note:
Differentiating between mass
and weight is not necessary at
this grade level.

09689BC7D0494A168F845104633BB73A.description: Engage in discussions about foods and what you eat.

E219FCE5E9ED45AD94FBD4F2D8235778.description:
Demonstrate the use of energy by moving parts of the
body.

9040B11D5457486D8CBAE6DA8E097BB5.description:
Identify the organisms that make up our food choices. (If
it is an animal source, ask students where that animal got
its energy from. If it is a plant, where did the plant get its
energy?. Use this information to build a simple food chain/
web.)

35EFBEEEF7354B918642FC7794D980D7.description:
Feel the heat and see the light from the sun on a sunny
day.

5D4788C8095745A3A4D2EED9BA9C42CF.description:
Identify that vitamin D is produced in the body with 10-15
minutes of sun exposure on arms, legs, or torso.

B7BEFDA846124E8CB418781AD7025ED0.description:
Recognize that most organisms depend on the sun’s
energy.

5DB0C9BE06164AE6B39223324B08865D.description:
Recognize that the sun’s energy gets transformed
into energy for plants which gets consumed by other
organisms.

23E5595E50104D7483B9418BADA3067D.description:
Construct a model of a food web showing the sun with
arrows illustrating the flow of energy.

01D0F7696A454195A472FC5F791EC057.description:
Identify
ways that
organisms can
obtain energy.

69A611C3297E450691FE8A8F8D1E03E1.description:
Identify that
producers transform
sun energy into
energy it uses to grow
and that consumers
get their energy to
grow by a transfer of
energy from another
organism.

4607BA8522C8403CBF057436A8389913.description:
Use
a food web to
explain how an
organism can get
a constant flow of
energy.

5587480D30434B6ABF8E652263DCEBFB.description:
All of the processes
that take place within
organisms require energy. For
most ecosystems, the major
source of energy is sunlight.
Energy entering ecosystems
as sunlight is transformed
by producers through the
process of photosynthesis.
That energy is used or stored
by the producer and can be
passed from organism to
organism as illustrated in food
webs.

95C66EE2A41B46218AE409B5F283B2E7.description:
Engage with pictures of various organisms (plants and
animals).

F945C8FC6EC547C4A237077D8DF68385.description:
Engage in following a path of energy on a food web (e.g.,
trace arrows on a food chain).

F802CD8282EA45ECA98DE832DAD37753.description:
Given a picture of an ecosystem, identify all the living
things.

A34737F3901247AE9838D1DED061431F.description:
Identify living things as producers (plants) or consumers
(animals).

73B359E0B4AB4D3CB29E51B2199182F0.description:
In an ecosystem determine who eats who and show the
energy flow using arrows (e.g., a food chain illustrating
deer eating grass, wolves eating deer etc.).

3F07F8BDCCA34981A59FE4285C5D0C92.description:
Recognize that organisms interact and depend on one
another.

3E6218ADAD9B4F919C00060146EB2E93.description:
Match pictures of consumers and producers with their
roles (herbivores, carnivores, omnivores, decomposers).

A239B2FB10C0404EBC214DB39C42AB5B.description:
Choose pictures to illustrate the various symbiotic
relationships;, mutualism, parasitism and commensalism.
(Show a picture of bees and flowers and describe the
relationship between the two organisms. Bees pollinate
flowers and the bee gets energy. Both roles are important
for survival.)

E550DC607225471BAAAE93D5CB254D64.description:
Sequence
components of a
simple food chain.

30E5146017EF4639858603182313F0B8.description:
Identify
a producer,
consumer, and
decomposer.

68BC30064C5E40C5BEEE55EB68B1256A.description:
Sequence
components of a food
web.

79CABDD17D6A4292881B6CCFB3AF3844.description:
Given a set
of organisms, match
them to their roles in a
food web.

33EEDB67AEBB4D01A0F6FC24A8227AB9.description:
Trace
the flow of energy
through a food
web.

8EB9DDE7E49D400DA3ACA2F826F6F25B.description:
Explain the role
of a producer,
consumer, or
decomposer in a
food web.

4D2CE71648F34E2D83720BF75127BF88.description:
Organisms perform
a variety of roles in an
ecosystem. Populations of
organisms can be categorized
by how they acquire energy.
Food webs can be used to
identify the relationships
among producers, consumers,
and decomposers in an
ecosystem.

FDA9C5678B3141148A2FA999A4414B09.description:
Engage in movement of models of the Earth, moon, and sun
(e.g., spinning and moving around other objects).

10F534F49C4B499D98D494571C887FFE.description: Model day and night onwith Earth with a ball and a flashlight.

9A7EAE64638C4E93BB7D70935C3EA5C7.description:
Identify that Earth’s rotation causes day and night. (Show videos
to illustrate the movement of the stars in the night sky.)

FD115B5C331F427EB3F807AA3908F248.description: Identify “rotation” as a spinning around a given point.

11109DF33EBF4D7FA479D8181EF81CF4.description: Recognize that Earth makes one rotation every 24 hours.

7A2649724313425AA9A26F767F6A3D91.description:
Make a model representing the sun and Earth’s rotation to
illustrate the difference between day and night.(e.g., Turn off the
lights in the room, turn on a lamp, bulb or flashlight on one side
of the room, turn in a circle, explain that you only see the lamp
when you are facing it.)

DC23BFA15602434A8CDF9DB49EF9B0D6.description: Describe differences between day and night (dark at night).

D716EF472E514E0FB4070300DE0EE706.description:
Map the position of the sun across the sky throughout the day.
(Watch the shadow of an object throughout the school day to
illustrate the movement of the sun, use a stick or pole in the sun
and draw a line (chalk on pavement, or paper placed under the
stick) for the shadow each hour of the school day.)

9E3F2322B5AC4FFF9E1B86CCF0979BC3.description:
Model revolution of an object moving in an orbital pattern around
another object (Earth and sun).

4608558B8DAE419797EF04CF43CC72E4.description:
Identify “revolution” as movement around another object in a
path.

816F16638BC74C2E855C1D9D6020F17D.description:
Use a model to show that Earth orbits the sun, recognize that
this is called revolution.

9733C992B79748DCB9B8636622FEC5BC.description:
Recognize that Earth makes one revolution every 365 days (or
one year).

DEB2CED1CE664A32AB985B6AC17381BA.description:
Identify the year can be broken down into seasons (summer, fall,
winter, spring)

7E1399EFAB8A403885A0336331A0B22D.description:
Match seasonal characteristics to number of daylight hours and
a visual representation of the positions of the Earth and sun.

D401EC71E7FC4E97ACBCE9B2ADB403C4.description:
Observe images of the night sky at different seasons to witness
the change in visible constellations.

0C526A0F55EC45F99FC2F33AD6819077.description:
Track and record sunrise, sunset times throughout the year and
calculate the number of daylight hours.

DBFF65A17756455F8633A0A1628470FE.description:
Use data of daylight hours to show how the number of daylight
hours changes season-to-season.

1969267803C34309A03F2F9B1CD5F9B6.description:
Identify
patterns that
result from Earth’s
revolution and
rotation.

A3E386F7F5614F00934AB1A5662AA9B7.description:
Sort
patterns into those
that result from
Earth’s revolution and
those that result from
Earth’s rotation.

1950DC8A324D4919B43567D78C053C2C.description:
Explain
the difference
between Earth’s
revolution and
Earth’s rotation.

321C64EBF90C4C999E9F3B066637F3E0.description:
Most of the cycles
and patterns of motion
between the Earth and sun
are predictable. Earth’s
revolution around the sun
takes approximately 365 days.
Earth completes one rotation
on its axis in a 24-hour period,
producing day and night. This
rotation makes the sun, stars,
and moon appear to change
position in the sky

DC13E4A3254849C6827D708D51CF8D73.description:
Feel the heat of the sun on a sunny day. (Set a thermometer in a
cup of water in the sun and watch the temperature rise.)

962FDC610D5B42858A4D281280B45493.description: Understand that stars (including the sun) give off heat and light.

72ACC72112A5426292D557B1ADF50269.description:
Engage in and compare in various visual representations of stars
(e.g., 5 point star versus a NASA picture of the sun).

2D682EEDC1774C01A98FE7C934159BE0.description: Identify the sun as a star.

A8EED2F30727477CAD9C08C6BA5E04D5.description: Recognize that the sun is our closest star.

6F400586298544D6B25720C588463ECA.description: Identify the sun as our primary source of energy.

EA291ACE6FDB48F193BEF43618C282A2.description: Identify the sun as the star, celestial body, of our solar system.

1BD673AC600249FF9F3AD49BAD988A86.description: Recognize that the sun is the only star in our solar system.

A1B35C24EDF141348F1FBB47705F7F0C.description:
Enrichment: Given several pictures of groups of stars, choose
one and tell what it looks like (tree, bear, snake, cloud, etc). Tell
an imaginary story about the object, use this to understand that
people made up constellations and stories about them.)

8A076384942A4C50A23695CCFC2B34AC.description:
Identify groups of stars as constellations (Can discuss how
people could use the star patterns to tell time and navigate
before we had modern technology). Watch videos of the
movement in the night sky, recognize that the stars always move
in the same pattern .

401CECFE20D241BC96D1474F97E8E00E.description:
Identify our sun as a medium star. (Look at pictures, charts,
graphs or videos to compare sizes of stars.)

8AC99AC9134E4769B9DAD14FFE01C1D0.description: Recognize that the sun is one of many stars in the universe.

4FCA64D8C5FC47C386C2AFC6E38F4FC0.description:
Recognize that stars in the universe can be close or far away
similar to everyday objects (e.g., Look at the same object (cup)
when it is near you body, measure it with you thumb and index
finger, see how its size changes when it is across the room),
use this to understand that giant stars look tiny to us on Earth
because they are very far away (you could also look at houses or
trees out the window and discuss that the house is not actually
only 1 inch high).

E4C5835EF7974370BCBB9C612814DB58.description: Explain that our sun is brightest because it is closest to Earth.

FD714B1E71AC4C90A8E6924F0329E15F.description:
Identify
the characteristics
of the Sun that
make it a star.

96A349E65B8B46B6AD30A93A5AD9972A.description:
Identify a visual
representation of a
constellation.

61985084B4254266B5D98D4ECCC5FEFD.description:
Identify
that the Sun is a
star and that the
Sun is the only
star in our solar
system.

458E5DDC030E404DAE3DC4A1CB2FBF31.description:
Describe
the characteristics of
the Sun that make it
a star.

B23CE0D8ED714C7AAE9E2EABD199E31B.description:
Explain
that the pattern
of stars within a
constellation stays
constant.

A916A9C5CDCF449AB116BEA83DD455E0.description:
Explain
the relationship of
our Sun to our solar
system and to our
universe.

A1588EFC889A4BB889F66CBAE41A1B49.description:
Compare the
characteristics of
different stars (e.g.,
size, brightness,
age).

9E7F8F3B69964906B50AB2B1B1A7D2B7.description:
Explain how a
constellation
can be used for
navigation.

F79A1BC001C94C8C97A7D35E52B41CE1.description:
Compare the Sun
to stars beyond our
solar system.

98DAFE600F31451CAB4AF404042F6DF7.description:
The sun is one of
many stars that exist in the
universe. The sun appears
to be the largest star in the
sky because it is the closest
star to Earth. Some stars are
larger than the sun and some
stars are smaller than the sun.

7A0B3FB43D844DD59AE17838E16EE54E.description: Engage with visual or tactile models of celestial bodies and/or the solar system.

4655EA124590462791C2835BB40D9DC9.description:
Engage with structural materials that make up celestial bodies (rocky materials, ice,
water, gases)

1EACE6EACB004436A944FFBE82FA807A.description:
Engage in the movement of celestial bodies (planets, moons, comets, asteroids) in
the solar system.

81E0DF20A3FE43BA97E349AF6FA87CFB.description:
Engage in activities that demonstrate gravity as a force (dropping a ball, jumping,
etc.).

7123DE9A7B6F466DA21AAE3E95AC73BE.description: Recognize a photo of the sun.

AC47CC9E501C4B23BCDBBA45DD1F0814.description: Recognize a photo of the moon.

F26388B863104AD1A4A212310305C1C1.description: Identify the celestial body (Earth) where we live.

FD26CD0A582F4C73812D8F97D599152A.description: Recognize a graphic representation or drawing of the solar system.

43CEF363F79343B1B43E5C3B51B81648.description:
Identify other celestial bodies (asteroids, dwarf planets, meteoroids) of the solar
system.

EAD3D2831FFE4411AC8EE07FD7031500.description: Trace the path that Earth follows around the sun on a diagram.

55B7C355E8304E749F002302555DDBCA.description: Trace the path that the moon follows around Earth on a diagram.

FE91F3BDE266479DB001226ED5D3E375.description: Identify the composition of Earth and inner planets (rocky planets).

F9A3F64FEE8047468A8337745DC55BAF.description: Identify the composition of outer planets (gaseous).

1A5AC6894A2C4EDF91CFB5C77C380488.description:
On a graphic of the solar system, recognize that rocky planets are near the sun and
gas planets are further away.

EF882B3DC51649F18575118F8AF5EC3A.description: Compare the size of the inner and outer planets.

FA4727E52B8045E2A0B021A33FD872C5.description:
Match pictures of the planets in our solar system with descriptions of them (e.g.,
for Jupiter made of gas, largest planet, 5th planet from sun, has a giant red spot
hurricane)

EDBBF750BED542F6B494D728DC87634F.description:
Demonstrate the movement of planets around the sun in an orbit (e.g., Twirl a
plastic ball on a string in a circle on the table, understand that this is how planets
and moons orbit, indicate that the string exerts a force towards your hand just like
gravity pulls on planets.).

BD422C15AB5149D393163A3381BC35FB.description:
Recognize that gravity holds the planets in orbit (e.g., roll a marble around a paper
plate with a wedge cut out that has a dab of paint right before the cut out. Use the
paint trail as the marble leaves the plate to see that a planet would fly away in a
straight line if gravity was not causing it to orbit the sun.)

9BAD7B9123514F90AE365D2894CC33CB.description:
Build a model of a comet. (e.g., Freeze muddy water in a paper cup, use it to depict
a comet and to show what happens when it orbits near the hot sun by letting it sit
out for a short time (some melts off the outside and it gets smaller)).

440F5898D96146D28360B4D46BF558DA.description:
Identify
Earth’s place in our
solar system.

D13C7977BA55413EBF13EE7D41AC47E3.description:
Identify
a representation
of an orbital path
within our solar
system.

CEB4372A02884E859B8E270ABEB93A72.description:
Identify
celestial bodies in
our solar system.

75634FE8D9D742FFB02A44B0F854E9C7.description:
Match
the composition of
the major planets
as related to their
position in the solar
system (e.g., rocky
planets are close to
the sun, gas giants
are further from sun).

1EF7787B7DAE4043BB47E7C1B25FF661.description:
Identify
examples of celestial
objects that are
being affected by a
gravitational force
resulting in an orbit.

F9B715930E7A46D097467E6579D32FD4.description:
Match a
set of descriptions to
the corresponding set
of celestial bodies.

4E13FAEACB8D408BB4E0BAA8880F59B5.description:
Compare the
composition and
sizes of the major
planets.

C021423978484B198CA752888D9A1510.description:
Explain what would
happen to orbits
if there was no
gravitational force.

3EC29980BCA54591ACF8F318FEF8B958.description:
Compare
different celestial
bodies including
composition and
size.

86B571FD9067434695F3188957BBEF86.description:
The solar system
includes the sun and all
celestial bodies that orbit
the sun. Each planet in
the solar system has
unique characteristics. The
distance from the sun, size,
composition, and movement
of each planet are unique.
Planets revolve around the
sun in elliptical orbits. Some
of the planets have moons
and/or debris that orbit them.
Comets, asteroids, dwarf
planets, and meteoroids also
orbit the sun.
